Yes, the reference to the earth in Job 16:18 is indeed related to the theology of land in the Old Testament. In the ancient Near Eastern worldview, the earth was seen as a physical manifestation of God's justice. If someone was unjustly killed, the earth was expected to "open its mouth" and swallow up the blood of the victim, thereby crying out for justice on their behalf.

Therefore, when Job says "O earth, do not cover my blood," he is appealing to this theological understanding of the earth as a symbol of justice and asking it not to cover up his own unjust death. He is essentially saying that his death should not be ignored or forgotten, but should be remembered and acknowledged as a cry for justice.

This reference to the earth also shows the deep sense of despair that Job feels, as he feels that God is not responding to his cries for help and justice. By appealing to the earth as a symbol of justice, Job is expressing his hope that even if God does not respond, the earth will still cry out for him.
